metadata.titleEn: HiWATER: Dataset of flux observation matrix (No.9 eddy covariance system) of the MUlti-Scale Observation EXperiment on Evapotranspiration over heterogeneous land surfaces 2012 (MUSOEXE-12)
metadata.description:
This dataset contains the flux measurements from site No.9 eddy covariance system (EC) in the flux observation matrix from 4 June to 17 September, 2012. The site (100.38546° E, 38.87239° N) was located in a cropland (maize surface) in Yingke irrigation district, which is near Zhangye, Gansu Province. The elevation is 1543.34 m. The EC was installed at a height of 3.9 m; the sampling rate was 10 Hz. The sonic anemometer faced north, and the separation distance between the sonic anemometer and the CO2/H2O gas analyzer (Gill&Li7500A) was 0.2 m.
Raw data acquired at 10 Hz were processed using the Eddypro post-processing software (Li-Cor Company, http://www.licor.com/env/products/ eddy_covariance/software.html), including spike detection, lag correction of H2O/CO2 relative to the vertical wind component, sonic virtual temperature correction, angle of attack correction, coordinate rotation (2-D rotation), corrections for density fluctuation (Webb-Pearman-Leuning correction), and frequency response correction. The EC data were subsequently averaged over 30 min periods. Moreover, the observation data quality was divided into three classes according to the quality assessment method of stationarity (Δst) and the integral turbulent characteristics test (ITC), which was proposed by Foken and Wichura [1996]: class 1 (level 0: Δst<30 and ITC<30), class 2 (level 1: Δst<100 and ITC<100), and class 3 (level 2: Δst>100 and ITC>100), representing high-, medium-, and low-quality data, respectively. In addition to the above processing steps, the half-hourly flux data were screened in a four-step procedure: (1) data from periods of sensor malfunction were rejected; (2) data before or after 1 h of precipitation were rejected; (3) incomplete 30 min data were rejected when the missing data constituted more than 3% of the 30 min raw record; and (4) data were rejected at night when the friction velocity (u*) was less than 0.1 m/s. There were 48 records per day; the missing data were replaced with -6999. Moreover, suspicious data were marked in red.
The released data contained the following variables: data/time, wind direction (Wdir, °), wind speed (Wnd, m/s), the standard deviation of the lateral wind (Std_Uy, m/s), virtual temperature (Tv, ℃), H2O mass density (H2O, g/m^3), CO2 mass density (CO2, mg/m^3), friction velocity (ustar, m/s), stability (z/L), sensible heat flux (Hs, W/m^2), latent heat flux (LE, W/m^2), carbon dioxide flux (Fc, mg/ (m^2s)), quality assessment of the sensible heat flux (QA_Hs), quality assessment of the latent heat flux (QA_LE), and quality assessment of the carbon flux (QA_Fc). In this dataset, the time of 0:30 corresponds to the average data for the period between 0:00 and 0:30; the data were stored in *.xlsx format.
For more information, please refer to Liu et al. (2016) (for multi-scale observation experiment or sites information), Xu et al. (2013) (for data processing) in the Citation section.

background: The two-source energy balance (TSEB) model was successfully applied to estimate evaporation (E), transpiration (T), and evapotranspiration (ET) for land covered with vegetation, which has significantly important applications for the terrestrial water cycle and water resource management. One-source evapotranspiration estimation models combine the soil–vegetation components into a single source. However, in real landscape conditions, the surface is heterogeneous and contains a mixture of soil and vegetation having different temperatures and resistance to energy exchange. Therefore, one-source models explicitly cannot estimate the surface evapotranspiration accurately because the effect of.

Shuttleworth and Wallace proposed a typical two-source evapotranspiration estimation model in which the energy partition is assumed to occur in both “the above canopy” and “the under soil” cases. Water vapor and heat meet over the reference height in the interior of the canopy. Moreover, the mixed water vapor and heat can only exit through the top of the canopy; the total heat flux is in addition to the fluxes coming from every surface layer. However, the model is complex, having over five resistances that cannot be accurately calculated. In addition, the model includes required parameters and observations that cannot be readily obtained from operational satellite- and ground-based data; therefore, the range of applications of the model is limited.

The TSEB model has undergone several revisions, improving the estimation of soil and canopy net radiation, the aerodynamic resistance of the soil surface, the fractional vegetation coverage observed at the radiometer view angle, the distribution of regional-scale near-surface air temperature, and soil and canopy component temperatures. Because the TSEB model only requires the surface energy balance model with a single measurement of land surface temperature, the original model and subsequent refinements have been widely used to estimate E and T under a wide variety of vegetation types, vegetation coverage, climates, and spatial scales. However, most studies have only evaluated the total fluxes or ET (soil plus canopy) in comparison with measurements using the Bowen ratio–energy balance system, the eddy covariance (EC) system, or the large aperture scintillometer.

Accurately estimating surface fluxes in a strongly advective irrigated agricultural area is a particularly challenging task and is even more difficult when the EC flux measurements of H and LE have an incomplete energy balance closure with respect to the available energy Rn−G0. The previous sensitivity studies found that the TSEB model performance is mainly affected by the uncertainty in surface–air temperature difference. Sometimes, this difference is dominant due to the errors in determining the surface soil and vegetation component temperatures from the surface composite radiometric temperature. In this letter, it is shown that there is an overestimation of the component temperatures compared with the observed composite radiometric. This often leads to the most crucial effect on the TSEB model performance. In addition, another factor is the strong advective environment in this region.
research objective: In this letter, the ground-measured soil and canopy component temperatures were used to estimate E, T, and ET, which were better validated with observed ratios of E (E/ET%) and T (T/ET%) using the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotopes, and the ET measurements using an eddy covariance (EC) system.

The objective of this letter is to estimate E, T, and ET using the soil and canopy component temperatures observed via a high-resolution thermal camera as inputs to a series TSEB model and to subsequently better validate E, T, and ET using a combination of the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotope technique and EC measurements.
challenges: However, the current composite temperature separation approaches are limited in their effectiveness in arid regions. Moreover, E and T are difficult to measure on the ground.

Errors in the derived component temperature were primarily caused by image classification errors; these classification errors varied with vegetation abundance. The higher uncertainty of H estimation is not only caused by the uncertainty of the TSEB model but also due to the increased uncertainty of the EC system, which is 18% when the mean H is small in the irrigated farmland. Due to image pixel classification errors, soil pixels were counted as vegetation pixels, which produced an overestimation of the canopy temperature under the developing vegetation abundance. Alternatively, ignoring atmospheric upwelling radiation and transmittance could have produced the uncertainties in the estimated temperatures. In addition, the estimated uncertainty of the incoming short- and long-wave radiation transmittances through the canopy may be another source of Rn estimation errors.
methods: In this letter, the field observations were obtained from the Daman superstation installed in the central oasis, which is a 40-m boundary layer tower located at 100.3722° E, 38.8555° N and at an elevation of 1556 m. The meteorological parameters were measured every 10 min and included air temperature, wind speed, humidity at 5 m over the ground, four-component radiations (measured at 12 m above the ground using a four-component radiometer), and turbulent fluxes (measured at 4.5 m above the ground using an EC system with a sampling frequency of 10 Hz). The soil heat fluxes were measured using three heat plates located 6 cm under the ground. A Fluke Ti55 thermal infrared camera was manually operated on a 25-m-high platform on a boundary layer tower to measure the thermal radiation of the cropland approximately every 120 min; the observations were collected as thermal images from approximately 07:00 to 19:00 China Standard Time (CST) during the daytime. The ground-based measurement data were applied to partition ET into E and T applying the Craig–Gordon model.

To evaluate the TSEB model accurately, the soil heat flux was using the ground measurement. In addition, the soil and canopy sensible heat fluxes were estimated using the series TSEB model, and their latent heat fluxes were calculated while solving the energy balance equations (1) and (2), respectively. The soil and canopy component temperatures were calculated using the images obtained with the thermal camera. To calculate the component temperatures, the visible and NIR images were classified into soil and canopy pixels using the maximum-likelihood method. Next, the soil and canopy directional brightness temperatures were exacted from the thermal images. Finally, the thermal infrared temperatures were converted to the radiation temperatures using the incoming long-wave radiation from the sky and the soil and canopy emissivities. Next, the simulated radiometric temperatures were validated against the surface radiometric temperatures, which were calculated according to the incoming long-wave radiation observed by the four-component radiometer.
dataset: The experimental area is an artificial oasis that is covered with maize, vegetables, and orchards. Data of day of year (DOY) 170, 173, 176, 192, 195, 231, 252, and 256 were used to determine ET and the ratios of E (E/ET%) and T (T/ET%) to ET during the Multi-Scale Observation Experiment on Evapotranspiration over heterogeneous land surfaces, which was part of the Heihe Water Allied Telemetry Experimental Research (HiWATER-MUSOEXE).
findings: Our results indicated that even under the strongly advective conditions, the TSEB model produced reliable estimates of the E/ET% and T/ET% ratios and of ET. The mean bias and root-mean-square error (RMSE) of E/ET% were 1% and 2%, respectively, and the mean bias and RMSE of T/ET% were −1% and 2%, respectively. In addition, the model exhibited relatively reliable estimates in the latent heat flux, with mean bias and RMSE values of 31 and 61 W·m−2, respectively, compared with the measurements from the EC system. These results demonstrated that a robust soil and vegetation component temperature calculation was crucial for estimating E, T, and ET. Moreover, the separate validation of E/ET% and T/ET% provides a good prospect for TSEB model improvements.

Our results demonstrated that the TSEB model using soil and canopy component radiometric temperatures, which were obtained from a high-precision thermal infrared camera, can be applied in a strongly advection-irrigated agricultural area. Notably, the results illustrated that the latent fluxes of the soil and vegetation components were successfully separated with reasonable accuracy, as assessed using ground-based measurements. The estimated E/ET% and E/ET% values agreed well with the values observed using the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotopes technique during the early, middle, and late growing seasons. In addition, the TSEB model produced reliable estimations of Rn, H, and LE; the mean biases of Rn, H, and LE were −18, 5, and 31 W ·m−2, respectively, and the RMSEs of Rn, H, and LE were 29, 19, and 61 W · m−2, respectively. This finding suggests that given accurate soil and vegetation component temperatures, E and T can be accurately separated from ET using the TSEB model.

background: Upscaling of eco-hydrological processes on a heterogeneous surface is a grand challenge. Progress in this field is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations. HiWATER is an experiment designed to address this challenge through instrumentation on hierarchically nested scales to obtain multiscale and multidisciplinary data.
challenges: Progress in this field is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations.
methods: Several intensive observation periods (IOPs) and continuous hydrometeorological observations were carried out during HiWATER. Only data collected during the IOP in 2012 are presented in this paper. Instruments for the oasis-desert system were arranged in hierarchically nested scales to capture multi-scale eco-hydrological processes. We established a sparse network to investigate the oasis-desert interaction. One superstation was constructed within the oasis, and four EC towers and four two-layer automatic meteorological stations (AMSs) were installed in different landscapes surrounding the oasis, including sandy desert, desert pavement, desert steppe, and wetland. Intensive observations were implemented at the irrigation district scale. A total of 12 airborne remote sensing missions were conducted to cover the FEA using LiDAR, an imaging spectrometer, a multi-angle thermal imager, and an L-band microwave radiometer.
dataset: We introduce a multiscale dataset obtained from Heihe Watershed Allied Telemetry Experimental Research (HiWATER) in an oasis-desert area in 2012. The HiWATER observation system consists of a flux observation matrix of eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, and automatic meteorological stations; an eco-hydrological sensor network of soil moisture and leaf area index; hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing using LiDAR, imaging spectrometer, multi-angle thermal imager, and L-band microwave radiometer; and synchronical ground measurements of vegetation dynamics and photosynthesis processes. All observational data were carefully quality controlled throughout sensor calibration, data collection, data processing, and datasets generation. The data are freely available at figshare and the Cold and Arid Regions Science Data Centre.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method that effectively captures multi-scale eco-hydrological processes in heterogeneous landscapes?
Example.Answer: The HiWATER experiment is an example that addresses the challenge of capturing multi-scale eco-hydrological processes. It involves instrumentation on hierarchically nested scales, including a sparse network for oasis-desert interaction, a superstation within the oasis, eddy covariance towers, automatic meteorological stations, and various remote sensing technologies such as LiDAR and imaging spectrometers.

Example.Question: What is an example of a dataset that integrates ground-based measurements with remote sensing data to study evapotranspiration in agricultural areas?
Example.Answer: The dataset obtained from the Multi-Scale Observation Experiment on Evapotranspiration over heterogeneous land surfaces (part of HiWATER) is an example. It combines ground-based measurements, like those from eddy covariance systems, with data from high-resolution thermal cameras and remote sensing techniques, to study evapotranspiration in an agricultural oasis.

Feature Specification.Answer: complexity of accurately calculating resistances and parameters, limited availability of required observational data, uncertainty caused by surface heterogeneity, errors in temperature component separation, strong advective environments

Comparison.Question: How do the data processing techniques like the Edire software used in flux observation datasets compare to the methods used for validating temperatures in the TSEB model using a high-resolution thermal camera?
Comparison.Answer: The Edire software processes raw 10Hz eddy covariance data into 30-minute intervals by applying steps such as outlier removal, time delay correction, angle correction, coordinate rotation, frequency response correction, sonic virtual temperature correction, and density correction. These processed data are then quality-checked for atmospheric stability and turbulence similarity. Meanwhile, for the TSEB model, the soil and canopy component temperatures are derived from thermal images captured by a high-resolution thermal camera. This involves classifying images into soil and canopy pixels, extracting brightness temperatures, and converting these to radiation temperatures using emissivities and incoming long-wave radiation data. Both approaches emphasize data quality and specific corrections but differ in focus: Edire software processes temporal flux data, while the TSEB model involves spatial temperature data validation.

Interpretation.Question: How do multiscale observations contribute to understanding eco-hydrological processes in oasis-desert environments?
Interpretation.Answer: Multiscale observations, facilitated by a hierarchical arrangement of instruments and intensive observation periods, enable comprehensive capture of various eco-hydrological processes. This approach addresses the limitation of poor availability of multiscale data, allowing for better investigation of complex interactions within oasis-desert systems.

Interpretation.Question: In what ways do thermal infrared cameras improve the accuracy of evapotranspiration estimates in agricultural settings?
Interpretation.Answer: Thermal infrared cameras enhance evapotranspiration accuracy by providing precise soil and canopy component temperatures. These temperatures are crucial for reliable latent flux separation and validation of the two-source energy balance model, leading to improved estimates of soil and vegetation latent heat fluxes under varying vegetation types and conditions.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the challenges in accurately estimating evapotranspiration over heterogeneous land surfaces using remote sensing data?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The challenges in accurately estimating evapotranspiration over heterogeneous land surfaces using remote sensing data are primarily due to the complexity of landscapes that mix soil and vegetation with different temperatures and resistances to energy exchange. Additionally, the need for parameters and observations that cannot be easily obtained from operational satellite- and ground-based data limits the application of models like the two-source energy balance (TSEB) model.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is it particularly difficult to achieve energy balance closure in eddy covariance flux measurements in strongly advective irrigated agricultural areas?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Energy balance closure in eddy covariance flux measurements is challenging in strongly advective irrigated agricultural areas due to uncertainties in surface-air temperature differences. These differences are often dominant because of errors in determining the surface soil and vegetation component temperatures from composite radiometric temperatures. The strong advective environment further complicates accurate flux estimation.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the high uncertainty in estimating sensible heat flux in irrigated farmland using the TSEB model?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The high uncertainty in estimating sensible heat flux in irrigated farmland using the TSEB model is caused by classification errors in image pixel data, where soil pixels may be misclassified as vegetation pixels. This leads to overestimation of canopy temperature, particularly under conditions of developing vegetation abundance. Additional factors include ignoring atmospheric upwelling radiation and uncertainties in estimating incoming short- and long-wave radiation transmittances through the canopy.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the implications of using a high-resolution thermal camera for measuring soil and canopy component temperatures in eco-hydrological studies?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using a high-resolution thermal camera allows for accurate measurement of soil and canopy component temperatures, which aids in better validation of evaporation, transpiration, and evapotranspiration estimates. This technique helps separate latent fluxes with reasonable accuracy, despite challenges like image classification errors and uncertainties in radiation transmittance.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the primary goal of employing a multiscale observation experiment to estimate evapotranspiration over heterogeneous land surfaces?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary goal is to address the challenge of accurately estimating evapotranspiration over heterogeneous surfaces by using a multiscale observation strategy. This approach allows for the capture of complex eco-hydrological processes that occur across different scales, providing a more comprehensive understanding and improving the accuracy of evapotranspiration estimates.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it essential to integrate both ground-based measurements and high-resolution thermal imagery in evaluating the two-source energy balance model?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Integrating ground-based measurements with high-resolution thermal imagery is essential for accurately evaluating the two-source energy balance model because it allows for precise estimation of soil and canopy component temperatures. This integration helps in overcoming the limitations of composite temperature separation methods in arid regions and improves the validation of evapotranspiration and its components.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are implemented to ensure the quality control of multiscale observational data in eco-hydrological research?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: In eco-hydrological research, quality control of multiscale observational data involves sensor calibration, data collection, data processing, and dataset generation. The data are carefully quality controlled throughout these stages to ensure accuracy and reliability.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How are eddy covariance systems utilized to measure turbulent fluxes in experimental areas with heterogeneous land surfaces?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Eddy covariance systems are used to measure turbulent fluxes by being placed at specific heights, such as 4.5 meters above the ground, and sampling at frequencies like 10 Hz. These systems help in accurately capturing the fluxes in areas with heterogeneous land surfaces, such as those covered with maize, vegetables, and orchards.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What instrumental approaches are employed to capture thermal radiation data for estimating evapotranspiration in agricultural regions?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: To capture thermal radiation data for estimating evapotranspiration in agricultural regions, a high-resolution thermal infrared camera is used. This camera is manually operated on a high platform to measure thermal radiation, and the data collected are then applied to estimate soil and canopy component temperatures, which are used in modeling evapotranspiration.

Enablement.Question: What observational instrumentation and techniques enable the collection of multiscale eco-hydrological data in heterogeneous landscapes?
Enablement.Answer: The collection of multiscale eco-hydrological data is enabled by a combination of hierarchically nested scales of instrumentation, including flux observation matrices of eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, automatic meteorological stations, eco-hydrological sensor networks for soil moisture and leaf area index, and hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing using LiDAR, imaging spectrometers, multi-angle thermal imagers, and L-band microwave radiometers.

Enablement.Question: In what ways do advanced remote sensing technologies enable the detailed monitoring of evapotranspiration over heterogeneous land surfaces?
Enablement.Answer: Advanced remote sensing technologies such as LiDAR, imaging spectrometers, and multi-angle thermal imagers enable detailed monitoring of evapotranspiration by providing high-resolution data that captures the spatial variability and dynamics of land surface characteristics, which are essential for accurately estimating evapotranspiration over heterogeneous landscapes.

Expectation.Question: Why might there be challenges in accurately estimating surface fluxes in heterogeneous landscapes using data collection methods?
Expectation.Answer: Accurately estimating surface fluxes in a strongly advective irrigated agricultural area is a challenging task due to incomplete energy balance closure in EC flux measurements and uncertainty in surface-air temperature differences. Errors in determining surface soil and vegetation component temperatures from the composite radiometric temperature also contribute to this challenge.

Expectation.Question: What are the expected benefits of using multiscale datasets in the observation of oasis-desert interactions, and why might such datasets be challenging to compile?
Expectation.Answer: Multiscale datasets provide comprehensive insights into oasis-desert interactions by capturing eco-hydrological processes at various scales. Compiling such datasets involves challenges like ensuring quality control across diverse instruments and observations, such as eddy covariance towers, remote sensing technologies, and ground measurements.

Judgmental.Question: How effective are the current data collection methods in capturing the multiscale eco-hydrological processes within heterogeneous landscapes?
Judgmental.Answer: The current data collection methods, as demonstrated in HiWATER, are quite effective in capturing multiscale eco-hydrological processes through the use of hierarchically nested scales, which include flux observation matrices, airborne remote sensing, and eco-hydrological sensor networks. However, progress in this field is still hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations, indicating room for further improvement in data capturing techniques.

Judgmental.Question: What challenges might researchers face in ensuring the accuracy of component temperature measurements in heterogeneous agricultural landscapes?
Judgmental.Answer: Researchers may face challenges such as image classification errors, which can vary with vegetation abundance, leading to inaccuracies in component temperature measurements. Additionally, ignoring atmospheric upwelling radiation and transmittance could contribute to uncertainties, as well as errors in estimating short- and long-wave radiation transmittances through the canopy, affecting the overall Rn estimation accuracy.

Judgmental.Question: Can the methodologies employed in the Two-Source Energy Balance (TSEB) model be considered robust for separating soil and vegetation latent heat fluxes in strongly advective environments?
Judgmental.Answer: The methodologies employed in the TSEB model using soil and canopy component radiometric temperatures are considered robust for separating soil and vegetation latent heat fluxes in strongly advective environments, as evidenced by reliable estimates of latent fluxes and accurate separation of E and T from ET. However, challenges such as uncertainties in surface-air temperature differences and image classification errors must still be addressed for improved accuracy.

Assertion.Question: I’m unsure about the challenges in obtaining multiscale eco-hydrological observations in heterogeneous landscapes.
Assertion.Answer: The challenge in obtaining multiscale observations is due to the poor availability of such data. HiWATER addressed this by using hierarchically nested scales to capture eco-hydrological processes, involving a sparse network and a superstation, multiple EC towers, AMSs, and intensive remote sensing missions to gather comprehensive data.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how datasets can be expanded to better understand evapotranspiration in heterogeneous land surfaces.
Assertion.Answer: Datasets can be expanded by utilizing a multiscale observation system like HiWATER, which combines eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, automatic meteorological stations, and remote sensing technologies such as LiDAR and imaging spectrometers, along with synchronized ground measurements of vegetation dynamics and photosynthesis.

Request/Directive.Question: Please analyze how multi-scale observation experiments can be designed to effectively capture eco-hydrological processes in oasis-desert systems.
Request/Directive.Answer: Multi-scale observation experiments, such as HiWATER, are designed with instrumentation at hierarchically nested scales, including flux observation matrices, eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, and automatic meteorological stations. This setup captures interactions between oases and surrounding deserts. Intensive observations are implemented at irrigation district scales, utilizing airborne remote sensing technologies like LiDAR and imaging spectrometers, combined with ground-based measurements to address the challenge of limited multiscale observations.
